Death of Noted Novelist Ends Career of
Man Who Made War Correpondents
a Power --Studied History Here,
Later Giving Manuscripts.

. Richard Harding Davis, the
noted war correspondent and novelist, who died of heart trouble last
Wednesday, for over a year was a.
member of the undergraduate department of this University.
Davis studied at Hopkins from
1885 to 1886. During that time he
specialized in history. Not much
can be told of his activities during
that time, but it is said that, even
then, he was more interested in the
search for adventure than in the
University curriculum.
Davis was born in Philadelphia
on April 18, 1864, and would have
been 52 years old this Tuesday.
His father was editor of a prominent Philadelphia paper, and his
mother was widely known as a
writer. Before coming to Hopkins,
Davis attended the Episcopal Academy in Philadelphia, and later
went to Lehigh University. Here
he wrote a series of stories for the
college magazine, which now are
among the most highly prized treasures of that publication.
After leaving Hopkins, Davis
immediately began his career as a
journalist, writing as a cub reporter
for the Philadelphia Press. His
first big assignment was in connection with the great Johnstown
flood of 1889. His first work as a
war correspondent, the field which
he was to make peculiarly his own,
came in 1907, when Greece was
struggling against Turkey. In
that war he represented the London Times and the New York
Herald, and his dispatches to those
papers form one of the most vivid
accounts of the war in existence.
The next several years of Davis'
life would have formed a fitting
model for the tale of one of his
own soldiers of fortune. From
Greece he went to Cuba, where he
followed Shafter's expedition. Next
he went to South America, then to
the Balkans, then to Manchuria.
and then to the Belgian Congo. In
1914 he left Vera Cruz to witness
-the world war, and had returned to
this country not a year ago.
Among the most famous of
Davis' books are "Soldiers of Fortune," "Gallegher and Other Stories," "Van Bibber," "Ranson's Folly," and "The King's Jackal." He
also wrote three plays: "The Dictator," "The Taming of Helen,"
and "The Galloper."
A few years ago Davis showed
the regard which he felt for this
University by presenting to it a
valuable collection of the manuscripts of famous American authors, which now hangs framed in
McCoy I-Tall.
"Have you e'er loved before?"
"Not enough to affect my amateur status, dearest," he replied.--

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 17, 1916.

DR. MORE CONCLUDES SERIES
Last of Turnbull Lectures Given Wednesday—New School of Verse Considered—Sidney Lanier Discussed on Monday.

HOPKINS MEN ATTEND
BURIAL OF DR. JONES

BASEBALL TEAM DEFEATS
CITY COLLEGE NINE

The burial of Dr. Harry Clary
Jones, professor of physical chemistry at Johns Hopkins University,
who died at his home Sunday, April
9, from potassium cyanide poisoning, took place April 12, 1916, near
Services
Frederick, Maryland.
were conducted at the home, Tuesday, April ii, by the Rev. Alfred
R. Hussey. There were present a
large number of professional men,
members of the Johns Hopkins
faculty, and some of Dr. Jones'
former pupils.
Those who acted as honorary
pallbearers were: Drs. Prank J.
Goodnow, Ira Remsen, Thomas S.
Cullen, Emmett Reed, Paul Haupt,
Maurice Bloomfield, H. N. Moses,
William H. Welch, F. P. Mall, W.
H. Howell, J. J. Abel, Howard A.
Kelly, Elliott Gilpin, David M.
Robinson, Harry Fielding Reid,
William Bullock Clark, R. Brent
Keyser, Albert Jones, Charles McHenry Howard, T. Poole Jones,
Eugene Levering and F. W. Wood.
The body was taken to Frederick
(and was accompanied) by members of Dr. Jones' family and intimate friends in the Uniirersitv
faculty.

The 'Varsity baseball team defeated City College in a practice
game at Homewood last Thursday, io to 3. The prep school
athletes put up a game fight, and
it was not until the seventh inning
that the 'Varsity was able, by a
great batting rally, to put the game
on ice. The hitting of both sides
was hard, several balls going into
the woods.
The grounds were wet and the
fielding in general was slow, although "Pete" Porter made a
couple of sensational plays. Wasser-.
man, Judifind, Defandorf and Gorman pitched for the 'Varsity and
all were effective, especially with
men on bases. Each had a couple
of strikeouts to his credit, and despite the wet condition of the ball,
only two or three bases on balls
were given.

On .\ I onday and Wednesday of
last week Paul Elmer More delivered the concluding lectures under
the Turnbull Foundation, the subjects being "Sidney Lanier" and
"The Modern Movement." These
completed the series of seven lectures on the "Poets of America."
The Monday lecture came somewhat unexpectedly to an audience
composed in large part of admirers
of Sidney Lanier, for Dr. Ailore's
criticism was by no means entirely
favorable. "Sidney Lanier," said
he, "set his eyes on a goal beyond
his reach, and too often used ideas
which he had not yet assimilated.
Judged from his whole work he
seems immature, for he came to his
full growth too late."
In the appointment of Lanier as
a lecturer, Dr. More said, Hopkins
was the first *university in the country to recognize the place of- pure
literature in a college curriculum.
He was a critic as well as a poet,
he continued, and one wonders
what might have been the result
had he not been so surrounded by
limitations, had he had opportunity

In Dr. Jones was exhibited to its
fullest extent the zeal of the worker. He was one of those men to
whom constant labor is an, actual
necessity; there was no delight to
him which could be measured with
the inspiration derived •from research and experiment; his life was
as varied, as exciting, as stimulating, as was that of any crusader.
He was one of the new men, an adventurous intellectual.
The sorrow which the entire University feels at his death is all the
more of a tribute in that, in every
case, it is tleeply personal.. He
was revered as a student, but he
was was loved as a man.

it intends to make that aptitude
rather wide-spread.
It may perhaps be considered
premature from the few weeks
that military training has been in
existence at Hopkins to draw conclusions as to what will be its permanent results. Yet, apart from all
considerations of duty and patriotism, to most of the University,
and especially to those who have
taken part in the movement, military training has already proved its
own justification.

al
Biggest Event on the Hopkins Soci
Calendar Takes Place on May 6.
Preparations Already
Under Way.
Palms are being trimmed, debi
tantes are planning gowns, Geor{
is making scathing references 1
the foolishness of it all, and Wa
ter is brushing the time-honor(
coat of tradition for, on May
comes the crowniug- event of ti
Hopkins social year, the magnu
opus, die Hauptsache der Haupts,
chen—the last cotillon.
Orders have been dispatched, ti
caterer, the floor-polisher, and ti
redoubtable Louis Fisher himse
all .are holding themselves in read
ness. The students are filling the
programs—even among the faculi
there stirs a faint and dig-,nifi(
wave of expectation. Examin
tions are a vague thing of the fl
ture ; all minds are fixed on dancir
pumps and partners.
The walls which have so oft(
reverberated to the thrilling tom
of the orator or to the wail of ti
eukelele once more will hear ti
swish of satin and the scrape (
feet tuned to sweet harmon,
About the dingy pillars of the basl
ment, redolent of the tobacco smot
of all the ages, once again wi
hover the faint and delicious pc
fume of gossamer and ruffles. 11
corridors dedicated to stern tene
of learning once more will shelt1
the windings of the fox-trottir
toe.
There are but three cotillons
year, and the greatest of these
the last. For it comes in the seasc
of straw hats and love—and then
in lies its might. Poets may lilt
the mysteries of spring, Russia
ballets may cavort in honor of i
splendor, but in McCoy Hall on]
will spring find its interpretatic
and its glory.

With lacrosse, track, baseball and
, last
tennis teams all in activity'
Saturday, Hopkins spring athletic
season had a somewhat spectacular
inauguration and the results of the
contests of that day, while not all
in favor of Hopkins, by the fight
which each one of the teams made,
justify the expectation that, in the
more crucial games of the season,
the University will make one of the
most successful showings of its history.
Despite the number of championships which have been won in a
sport, perhaps because of them, the
appearance of every successive
team is awaited with an anxiety
which sometimes tends to forget
the excellence of the system and the
caliber of the men which achieved
those championships. Yet the successive victories of the lacrosse
team• over the Alumni and over
Penn State are none the less reassuring. Those who witnessed the
perfect stick work, the close team
play, and the indomitable spirit with
which the 'Varsity players rollicked
time after time down the field for
a goal last Saturday, feel rather
confident of another national and
perhaps international championship for the Black and Blue.
The schedule of the baseball team
for this season is unusually good.
When such colleges as Harvard
and Yale send their teams to Homewood, it is a fairly good guarantee
that the team which they are going
to meet is of exceptionally high
caliber. Hopkins was nosed out
at Gettysburg by an unexpected
rally in the ninth inning, but the
game played by the 'Varsity would
seem to prove that, even akainst
the best collegiate teams of the
country, Hopkins will by no means
be doomed to defeat.
The track team alsp shows every
promise of successful development.

on the streets of Hamilton.

held against an exceptionally stron
team. Yet, even under these cot
ditions, Hopkins succeeded in wit
fling three first places against
large field, and, in addition, broil
Navy's record for the high-juml
The victory of the tennis teal
at Gettysburg is still, another it
dication both of the spirit and of tli
composition of the ;teams whic
Hopkins is turning out this yea
The University already has to i'
credit the football championship c
the state—and a. great year in th
history of athletics is not altogeth(

MUSICIANS SUCCESSFUL IN
CONCERT AT CITY COLLEGE

The Glee and Vandolin Clubs
gave a concert at the Baltimore City
College on Tuesday, April ii. The
concert was held for the night
schools, unde4- the auspices of the
Board of Education, and was poorly
attended. Both clubs carried off
the usual honors.
All efforts are being directed
toward the big concert which is to
be held in Washington on May 2.
The Hotel Raleigh ball-room has
been engaged for the occasion, and
it is highly probable that a dance
will . follow. A large representation of Washington society is expected.
The clubs will .also appear in
three more concerts before the close
of the season, the exact details of
which have not yet been announced.
Every indication points toward a
thorough financial success.
Music will be furnished by the
'Varsity quartet for the inter-collegiate debate on April 29. The
quartet has rapidly become popular,
and has obtained numerous engagements by virtue of its good work
at University occasions. At the
contest of the Peace Association it
made a thorough "hit," being required to give six encores to the
rendition of a medley of negro
songs. It is composed of E. M.
Spieker, '16, first tenor; I. L.
Houghton, '17, second tenor; R. F.
Fleck, '19, baritone, and R. E.
Swarts, Jr., basso.

BANQUET TO INITIATES

The initiation of the newly elected members of the Phi Beta Kappa
was held last Saturday night. The
dinner to the initiates was held immediately after the ceremony in
McCoy Hall.
Professor Abell was toastmaster
of the dinner, and after a few re- •
marks introduced the speaker of
the evening, Prof. John Dewey, of
the department of philosophy at
Columbia.
- Five members of this year's senior class, 8 graduate students, 12
medical students, 4 members of the
faculty, and i collegiate student of
the Class of '87 were initiated this
year.

Out of Twenty-Nine Men in Academic
Class, Nine Will Go Into Medicine.
Only Five Undecided as
to Profession.

The plans of the members of the
men of the Class of 1916 in the
academic department cover many
varied fields. As usual, the number
of men who intend to take up medicine as their life work tops the
list and compares favorably with
the number of prospective medical
students in former classes.
Graduate work comes second after medicine, followed by law, the
ministry and business. The scarcity of men who intend to become
lawyers is very marked, and the
average for this profession seems
low in comparison with those of
previous years.
Many of the men have definite
plans as to their profession, yet express doubts whether they will hold
to their present intentions. At present; however, the list of men and
professions is as follows:
First in number in the class are
those who intend to go to the Hopkins medical school: R. W. Baer,
G. N. Cromwell, R. E. Fricke, •J.
S. Friedenwald, M. G. Gichner, R.
W. Hale, A. A. Hardy, 0. B. Helfrich, A. C. Primrose.
Those intending to take graduate
work in various subjects consist of
F. K. Bell, K. S. Melamet, P. Milburn, Jr., E. Rosenthal, E. M.
Spieker and A. R. Stargardter.
Those who intend to take up law
are: M. E. Bagley, G. F. Ludington and T. J. Tingley.
Those intending to enter the
ministry and mission work are: E.
P. Hayes, missionary to China; R.
E. F. Aler and M. H. McCormick,
the ministry.
Those planning to enter business:
J. C. Knipp, C. W. McDowell and
C. H. Tinges.
Those undecided or unlisted: N.
M. Beck, H. C. Coffin, H. L. Dryden, R. Rosen and E. 0. Shaw.
Comparing the different professions, out of 29 men listed in the
class, medicine conies first with 9,
graduate work, second, with 6; law,
the ministry and business, third,
with 3 each, while those undecided
are 5.

The National City Bank of New
York has set a plan before the
faculty of Minnesota whereby it
will take students from fourteen
universities into its employ at $50
per month, and train them for
foreign service. The students are
to be chosen in their sophomore
year, must study the language ofthe country to which they wish to
be sent, and must work in the bank
•
two summers.
"Class scraps" were unanimously abolished at Penn State by a
mass-meeting of the student body.
At the same time, however, provisions were made whereby some
milder form of under-classmen activities may be introduced in their
stead.
One of the strangest methods of
earning money by college students
last year was that of blood transfusion. Twelve Harvard students
underwent this operation for which
each received $10.
In a recent report the dean of
Smith College refutes what she
says is the popular idea that the
college girl devotes a large part of
her time and money to amusing
herself.
Figures compiled from expense
accounts kept by all the 333 stu--.
dents for two months and by about
one-fourth of the total for the school
year show the average girl at
Smith spends 87.4 per cent, of her
money for necessities; 8.2 per cent.
for pleasure, including dues, recreation, contributions to church and
charity, and 4.2 per cent for books
and stationery.
The cutting evil at Yale University has been eliminated by means
of the "half-cut" system. If a student is unprepared, he may go to
class, signify that he does not wish
to recite, and be credited with onehalf cut. In this way he gets the
benefit of the lecture and the recitation. The system has proved very
satisfactory, both from the instructors' and the students' point of
view.
* *
Following the example set by
Minnesota, the honor system will be
introduced into football at the University of Pennsylvania next fall.
Each man will be placed on his
honor to keep in training and obey
regulations.

honor system which provides for
the abolition of class scraps, tabooing of posters and elimination of
Ii azing.
Dartmouth College has a dramatic association with a membership of 200 men. The association
presents a play every three weeks
with an entire change of cast.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 17, 1916.

CORPS DRILLING AT HOMEWOOD

CLUB MAKES RECORD SCORE

Developing Rapidly in Execution of
Movements--Is Now Organized in
Company Form—Leaders Take
Turns at Command.

Scores 989 Out of Possible 1000 Against
Rensslaer—Indoor Season Over.
Hopkins Near Top of
the League.

Although the volunteer battalion
of the Johns Hopkins University
has had only two weeks of training
in the rudiments of military drill,
the men have taken hold of the
movements so well that on last
Wednesday at the drill ground in
front of the Academic Building at
Homewood it was possible for the
corps to organize in the regular
company formation and take up
"squads right" and "squads left,"
the two fundamental movements in
the school of the company.
H. Winslow was appointed by
Mr. Kistler to take charge of the
company on that day, and the training progressed rapidly under his
supervision. After forming the
company and appointing the experienced men corporals, file-closers
and guides, he explained the movements to be taken up and then put
the squads in charge of their assigned leaders. These men, after
reviewing the movements previously practiced, instructed the squads
how to execute "squads right" and
"squads left." After a period devoted to the performance of these
orders, the squads were again assembled in company formation, and
the whole company was put
through various new commands.
On Friday practically the same
routine was followed with the company under the command of B.
Baxley, '17. Mr. Kistler had intended on that day to have the company elect temporary officers to act
until examinations could be taken
for official positions as commissioned officers, but after consultation
with the squad leaders decided to
reject the plan as premature. In
its stead a better system is to be
followed out. Each leader, in succession from graduate student
down to freshman, is to have charge
of the company for one day, to
show his ability at commanding and
instructing in military drill. After
the list has been gone through, the
leaders will have had practical experience in preparation for the examination and the authorities will
have had an opportunity to judge
more wisely of the fitness of the
,. men.
Another scheme which is now
being carried out, is a school for
officers, which occurs on Tuesday
at 5 o'clock at Homewood. All
the .commands which are to be
taken up at the next general drill,
and every detail which will make
the corps more efficient, are discussed at length. Mr. Kistler is
anxious that all leaders he present
at these meetings as it is mainly
upon them that the responsibility
for the success of the movement
rests.
It is also imperative that all those
who have signed up for military
training appear at the drills, which
occur on Monday, Wednesday and

The Johns Hopkins University
Rifle Team finished its indoor season on last Saturday with the
record of losing only two' matches
out of thirteen. Moreover, in its
match with Rensslaer, which took
place last week, our squad made the
highest aggregate score shot by any
of the thireen teams in the National
Rifle Association-989 out of a possible 1,000. With such a score, although the winner has not yet been
officially determined, it is absolutely
certain that Hopkins won an overwhelming victory over its opponent.
The scores made in this match
were 197 made by J. Sanner, '18,
196 by P. Wiggins, 199 by H. A.
Rowland, 199 by W. Pratt and 198
by J. W. Young. Another victory
for the Hopkins team was that over
Harvard on April 1, which tallied
984 for Hopkins and 978 for its
opponents. These two triumphs
are especially pleasing as both
teams defeated had always been at
or near the top of the league. In
the match with Harvard, J. E. Sanner led with 199, W. B. Pratt shot
198, H. A. Rowland made 197, J.
M. C. Van Hulsteyn shot 198 and
P. R. Wiggins tallied 195.
It is practically certain that our
team stands at least among the first
five in the league. Out of a possible 13,000 points on the thirteen
matches, Hopkins has scored 12,585,
the average score being 968. The
individual averages of the men on
the team are also very high. They
are as follows: Pratt, 196.5; Van
Hulsteyn, 192.1; Rowland, 191.4;
Chisholm, 190.3; Wiggins, 190.1;
Sanner, 189.5; Young, 188.3;
Smith, i86.8; Randall, 184.0, and
Konze, 179.1.
The success of the indoor season
justifies the hope that the Hopkins
squad will win first honors in the
coming spring season which lasts
from May 15 •to 21, at Saunders
Range, near Annapolis. The Krag
rifles, which the members of the
team received direct from the United States Government, have arrived, and the men are already
beginning to test them on outdoor
ranges. Practices are usually held
on Saturday at Saunders Range,
Annapolis, and the men's expenses
are paid both ways by the Government.

TO SEND PARTY TO EAGLES MERE
Y. M. C. A. Expects to Be Represented
by Large Delegation at Annual Students' Conference--Total Expense for Trip, $33.

\\ ith but half a dozen weeks of
the academic year remaining, the
Young Men's •Christian Association of this University is making
definite plans for its delegation at
the Middle Atlantic Students' Conference, which will be held, as
usual, at Eagles Mere Park, Pa.,
immediately after the University
closes.
The conference will open on June
16 and will continue for ten days.
The total expenses of the trip for
a delegate will be $33, which will
include railroad fare and board at
the hotels.
The conference this year is expected to be unusually successful.
Among the speakers and leaders
present will be John R. Moot,
Robert E. Speer, Raymond Robbins, Harry Emerson Fosdick and
Sherwood 'Eddy, all of whom have
a national and even world-wide
reputation.
The talks and meetings will not
confine themselves to the study of
mission work, but will take up
problems.which confront every man
in all spheres of activity.
The week is not spent, however,
entirely in lectures and conferences.
In fact, the greater part of the day
is spent on the lake, in the woods,
or in inter-collegiate rivalry. Many
colleges from this section of the
country are represented at the conference, among the number being
Princeton, University of Pennsylvania, Penn State, Lehigh and Cornell.
Hopkins has always sent about
a score of men to 'Eagles Mere,
and expects to send an even larger
delegation this summer. Those
who are interested should see
Franklin Sutton, chairman of the
Eagles Mere committee; Pearce
Hayes, or Mr. Lindley, all of whom
have descriptive folders for distribution.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 17, 1916.

10
TENNIS MEN DOWN GETTYSBURG

SUNDAY TALKS TO HOPKINS MEN

Team Wins First Contest of Season by
Score of Four Matches to Two.
Makes Strong Showing
in Doubles.

Given Enthusiastic. Reception—Praises
University in Talk—"Don't Be a Boil
on the Neck of the Body Politic," He Exhorts.

On Saturday afternoon, in their
first match of the season, playing
on their opponents ground, the
Hopkins tennis team defeated Gettysburg, four matches to two.
All the games played were fast
and exciting, and the form displayed by all the players would not
have disgraced a mid-season showing. The courts were in good condition, and a large crowd witnessed
the games.
In the singles, Hopkins split
even, winning two matches and
losing two, but it succeeded in winning both of the finals. At one
time only did things look dark for
the Black and Blue, when, in the
first game of the doubles, Seecrest
and Swartz of Gettysburg defeated
Hammond and Allen of Hopkins by
the score of 6 to 4. In a superb
rally, however, by means of excellent team-work, the two latter men
came back in the second game,
winning 6 to 4. From that time on,
the result was on longer in doubt,
Hopkins winning every other game.
On April 19 the tennis team will
play Navy at Annapolis, and on
April 21 will meet Princeton at
Homewood. With the excellent
start afforded by the defeat over
such a strong team as Gettysburg,
the Hopkins men are confident of a
highly successful season;
The score of last Saturday's
match:

On Friday afternoon, after many
weeks of expectation, the students
of Johns Hopkins University had
the privilege of being addressed by
Billy Sunday in their own hall.
At the hour of twelve, McCoy
Hall was filled to overflowing, and
the audience was already manifesting its excitement by frequent outbursts of applause and song. When
at last Mr. Sunday appeared on the
platform, accompanied by Rodeheaver, he was given a hullabaloo
whose volume left no doubt as to
the enthusiasm behind it.
Mr. Eugene Levering introduced
Mr. Sunday with a few brief remarks. Rodeheaver then advanced
with his invincible trombone and
began proceedings by reading a
notice of Saturday's lacrosse game.
It was to be regretted that Hopkins had not warmed up earlier in
the campaign, he said, so that such
notices might have been read regularly in the tabernacle. The colleges and Mr. Sunday had always
worked together, he went on, with
mutual success. He then announced
"a drama in three parts," and played
"Yankee Doodle,""Dixie" and "The
Star - Spangled Banner. McCoy
Hall has seldom heard wilder bursts
of applause than those which followed that "drama."
Mr. Sunday now advanced to the
front of the platform. "I never
dared to dream that I would ever
have the honor of addressing Johns
Hopkins University, a university
whose fame extends throughout the
land, in person," he began, "and I
want to thank you now for the
privilege you are according me."
Then he launched into his sermon.
"The real purpose of education
is not only to inculcate a few facts,"
he said, "it is to discipline hearts.
Not all the• time can be spent in
polishing your brains.
"When you die, you want to
leave something more behind you
than the epitaph on a tombstone.
The world will take you at your
own worth. 'You can fool all of
the people some of the time and you
can fool some of the people all of
the time, but you can't fool all of
the people all of the time.'
"Do a common thing in an uncommon way. When I was a boy,
I was a janitor in a building, and
it was then that I realized what
that meant for the first time. A
jack-of-all-trades can't support
himself, let alone any girl who is
fool enough to marry him.
"Do one thing well. Don't be a
carbuncle on the neck of the body
politic; Know more about your
business than any one else does.
"Be careful of your time. Idleness is one of the biggest curses
known to mankind. Be careful and
painstaking. 'Trifles make perfec-

Archie's Neck.

Little Willie—in small boy stories
the central figure is nearly always
named Little Willie—came running
into the house, stuttering in his excitement.
"Mommer," he panted, "do you
know Archie Sloan's neck?"
"Do I know what?" asked his
mother.
"Do you know Archie Sloan's
neck ?" repeated her offspring.
"I know Archie Sloan," answered
the puzzled parent; "so I suppose
I must know his neck. Why?"
"Well," said Willie,"he just now
fell into the back-water up to it."

Death of Noted Novelist Ends Career of
Man Who Made War Correpondents
a Power --Studied History Here,
Later Giving Manuscripts.

. Richard Harding Davis, the
noted war correspondent and novelist, who died of heart trouble last
Wednesday, for over a year was a.
member of the undergraduate department of this University.
Davis studied at Hopkins from
1885 to 1886. During that time he
specialized in history. Not much
can be told of his activities during
that time, but it is said that, even
then, he was more interested in the
search for adventure than in the
University curriculum.
Davis was born in Philadelphia
on April 18, 1864, and would have
been 52 years old this Tuesday.
His father was editor of a prominent Philadelphia paper, and his
mother was widely known as a
writer. Before coming to Hopkins,
Davis attended the Episcopal Academy in Philadelphia, and later
went to Lehigh University. Here
he wrote a series of stories for the
college magazine, which now are
among the most highly prized treasures of that publication.
After leaving Hopkins, Davis
immediately began his career as a
journalist, writing as a cub reporter
for the Philadelphia Press. His
first big assignment was in connection with the great Johnstown
flood of 1889. His first work as a
war correspondent, the field which
he was to make peculiarly his own,
came in 1907, when Greece was
struggling against Turkey. In
that war he represented the London Times and the New York
Herald, and his dispatches to those
papers form one of the most vivid
accounts of the war in existence.
The next several years of Davis'
life would have formed a fitting
model for the tale of one of his
own soldiers of fortune. From
Greece he went to Cuba, where he
followed Shafter's expedition. Next
he went to South America, then to
the Balkans, then to Manchuria.
and then to the Belgian Congo. In
1914 he left Vera Cruz to witness
-the world war, and had returned to
this country not a year ago.
Among the most famous of
Davis' books are "Soldiers of Fortune," "Gallegher and Other Stories," "Van Bibber," "Ranson's Folly," and "The King's Jackal." He
also wrote three plays: "The Dictator," "The Taming of Helen,"
and "The Galloper."
A few years ago Davis showed
the regard which he felt for this
University by presenting to it a
valuable collection of the manuscripts of famous American authors, which now hangs framed in
McCoy I-Tall.
"Have you e'er loved before?"
"Not enough to affect my amateur status, dearest," he replied.--

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 17, 1916.

DR. MORE CONCLUDES SERIES
Last of Turnbull Lectures Given Wednesday—New School of Verse Considered—Sidney Lanier Discussed on Monday.

HOPKINS MEN ATTEND
BURIAL OF DR. JONES

BASEBALL TEAM DEFEATS
CITY COLLEGE NINE

The burial of Dr. Harry Clary
Jones, professor of physical chemistry at Johns Hopkins University,
who died at his home Sunday, April
9, from potassium cyanide poisoning, took place April 12, 1916, near
Services
Frederick, Maryland.
were conducted at the home, Tuesday, April ii, by the Rev. Alfred
R. Hussey. There were present a
large number of professional men,
members of the Johns Hopkins
faculty, and some of Dr. Jones'
former pupils.
Those who acted as honorary
pallbearers were: Drs. Prank J.
Goodnow, Ira Remsen, Thomas S.
Cullen, Emmett Reed, Paul Haupt,
Maurice Bloomfield, H. N. Moses,
William H. Welch, F. P. Mall, W.
H. Howell, J. J. Abel, Howard A.
Kelly, Elliott Gilpin, David M.
Robinson, Harry Fielding Reid,
William Bullock Clark, R. Brent
Keyser, Albert Jones, Charles McHenry Howard, T. Poole Jones,
Eugene Levering and F. W. Wood.
The body was taken to Frederick
(and was accompanied) by members of Dr. Jones' family and intimate friends in the Uniirersitv
faculty.

The 'Varsity baseball team defeated City College in a practice
game at Homewood last Thursday, io to 3. The prep school
athletes put up a game fight, and
it was not until the seventh inning
that the 'Varsity was able, by a
great batting rally, to put the game
on ice. The hitting of both sides
was hard, several balls going into
the woods.
The grounds were wet and the
fielding in general was slow, although "Pete" Porter made a
couple of sensational plays. Wasser-.
man, Judifind, Defandorf and Gorman pitched for the 'Varsity and
all were effective, especially with
men on bases. Each had a couple
of strikeouts to his credit, and despite the wet condition of the ball,
only two or three bases on balls
were given.

On .\ I onday and Wednesday of
last week Paul Elmer More delivered the concluding lectures under
the Turnbull Foundation, the subjects being "Sidney Lanier" and
"The Modern Movement." These
completed the series of seven lectures on the "Poets of America."
The Monday lecture came somewhat unexpectedly to an audience
composed in large part of admirers
of Sidney Lanier, for Dr. Ailore's
criticism was by no means entirely
favorable. "Sidney Lanier," said
he, "set his eyes on a goal beyond
his reach, and too often used ideas
which he had not yet assimilated.
Judged from his whole work he
seems immature, for he came to his
full growth too late."
In the appointment of Lanier as
a lecturer, Dr. More said, Hopkins
was the first *university in the country to recognize the place of- pure
literature in a college curriculum.
He was a critic as well as a poet,
he continued, and one wonders
what might have been the result
had he not been so surrounded by
limitations, had he had opportunity

In Dr. Jones was exhibited to its
fullest extent the zeal of the worker. He was one of those men to
whom constant labor is an, actual
necessity; there was no delight to
him which could be measured with
the inspiration derived •from research and experiment; his life was
as varied, as exciting, as stimulating, as was that of any crusader.
He was one of the new men, an adventurous intellectual.
The sorrow which the entire University feels at his death is all the
more of a tribute in that, in every
case, it is tleeply personal.. He
was revered as a student, but he
was was loved as a man.

It may perhaps be considered
premature from the few weeks
that military training has been in
existence at Hopkins to draw conclusions as to what will be its permanent results. Yet, apart from all
considerations of duty and patriotism, to most of the University,

LAST COTILLON DRAWING NEA
al
Biggest Event on the Hopkins Soci
Calendar Takes Place on May 6.
Preparations Already
Under Way.
Palms are being trimmed, debi
tantes are planning gowns, Geor{
is making scathing references 1
the foolishness of it all, and Wa
ter is brushing the time-honor(
coat of tradition for, on May
comes the crowniug- event of ti
Hopkins social year, the magnu
opus, die Hauptsache der Haupts,
chen—the last cotillon.
Orders have been dispatched, ti
caterer, the floor-polisher, and ti
redoubtable Louis Fisher himse
all .are holding themselves in read
ness. The students are filling the
programs—even among the faculi
there stirs a faint and dig-,nifi(
wave of expectation. Examin
tions are a vague thing of the fl
ture ; all minds are fixed on dancir
pumps and partners.
The walls which have so oft(
reverberated to the thrilling tom
of the orator or to the wail of ti
eukelele once more will hear ti
swish of satin and the scrape (
feet tuned to sweet harmon,
About the dingy pillars of the basl
ment, redolent of the tobacco smot
of all the ages, once again wi
hover the faint and delicious pc
fume of gossamer and ruffles. 11
corridors dedicated to stern tene
of learning once more will shelt1
the windings of the fox-trottir
toe.
There are but three cotillons
year, and the greatest of these
the last. For it comes in the seasc
of straw hats and love—and then
in lies its might. Poets may lilt
the mysteries of spring, Russia
ballets may cavort in honor of i
splendor, but in McCoy Hall on]
will spring find its interpretatic
and its glory.

With lacrosse, track, baseball and
, last
tennis teams all in activity'
Saturday, Hopkins spring athletic
season had a somewhat spectacular
inauguration and the results of the
contests of that day, while not all
in favor of Hopkins, by the fight
which each one of the teams made,
justify the expectation that, in the
more crucial games of the season,
the University will make one of the
most successful showings of its history.
Despite the number of championships which have been won in a
sport, perhaps because of them, the
appearance of every successive
team is awaited with an anxiety
which sometimes tends to forget
the excellence of the system and the
caliber of the men which achieved
those championships. Yet the successive victories of the lacrosse
team• over the Alumni and over
Penn State are none the less reassuring. Those who witnessed the
perfect stick work, the close team
play, and the indomitable spirit with
which the 'Varsity players rollicked
time after time down the field for
a goal last Saturday, feel rather
confident of another national and
perhaps international championship for the Black and Blue.
The schedule of the baseball team
for this season is unusually good.
When such colleges as Harvard
and Yale send their teams to Homewood, it is a fairly good guarantee
that the team which they are going
to meet is of exceptionally high
caliber. Hopkins was nosed out
at Gettysburg by an unexpected
rally in the ninth inning, but the
game played by the 'Varsity would
seem to prove that, even akainst
the best collegiate teams of the
country, Hopkins will by no means
be doomed to defeat.
The track team alsp shows every
promise of successful development.

ty are to be allowed to smoke on]

on the streets of Hamilton.

held against an exceptionally stron
team. Yet, even under these cot
ditions, Hopkins succeeded in wit
fling three first places against
large field, and, in addition, broil
Navy's record for the high-juml
The victory of the tennis teal
at Gettysburg is still, another it
dication both of the spirit and of tli
composition of the ;teams whic
Hopkins is turning out this yea
The University already has to i'
credit the football championship c
the state—and a. great year in th
history of athletics is not altogeth(
a thing of fable.

MUSICIANS SUCCESSFUL IN
CONCERT AT CITY COLLEGE

The Glee and Vandolin Clubs
gave a concert at the Baltimore City
College on Tuesday, April ii. The
concert was held for the night
schools, unde4- the auspices of the
Board of Education, and was poorly
attended. Both clubs carried off
the usual honors.
All efforts are being directed
toward the big concert which is to
be held in Washington on May 2.
The Hotel Raleigh ball-room has
been engaged for the occasion, and
it is highly probable that a dance
will . follow. A large representation of Washington society is expected.
The clubs will .also appear in
three more concerts before the close
of the season, the exact details of
which have not yet been announced.
Every indication points toward a
thorough financial success.
Music will be furnished by the
'Varsity quartet for the inter-collegiate debate on April 29. The
quartet has rapidly become popular,
and has obtained numerous engagements by virtue of its good work
at University occasions. At the
contest of the Peace Association it
made a thorough "hit," being required to give six encores to the
rendition of a medley of negro
songs. It is composed of E. M.
Spieker, '16, first tenor; I. L.
Houghton, '17, second tenor; R. F.
Fleck, '19, baritone, and R. E.
Swarts, Jr., basso.

The initiation of the newly elected members of the Phi Beta Kappa

McCoy Hall.
Professor Abell was toastmaster
of the dinner, and after a few re- •
marks introduced the speaker of
the evening, Prof. John Dewey, of
the department of philosophy at
Columbia.
- Five members of this year's senior class, 8 graduate students, 12
medical students, 4 members of the
faculty, and i collegiate student of
the Class of '87 were initiated this
year.

Out of Twenty-Nine Men in Academic
Class, Nine Will Go Into Medicine.
Only Five Undecided as
to Profession.

The plans of the members of the
men of the Class of 1916 in the
academic department cover many
varied fields. As usual, the number
of men who intend to take up medicine as their life work tops the
list and compares favorably with
the number of prospective medical
students in former classes.
Graduate work comes second after medicine, followed by law, the
ministry and business. The scarcity of men who intend to become
lawyers is very marked, and the
average for this profession seems
low in comparison with those of
previous years.
Many of the men have definite
plans as to their profession, yet express doubts whether they will hold
to their present intentions. At present; however, the list of men and
professions is as follows:
First in number in the class are
those who intend to go to the Hopkins medical school: R. W. Baer,
G. N. Cromwell, R. E. Fricke, •J.
S. Friedenwald, M. G. Gichner, R.
W. Hale, A. A. Hardy, 0. B. Helfrich, A. C. Primrose.
Those intending to take graduate
work in various subjects consist of
F. K. Bell, K. S. Melamet, P. Milburn, Jr., E. Rosenthal, E. M.
Spieker and A. R. Stargardter.
Those who intend to take up law
are: M. E. Bagley, G. F. Ludington and T. J. Tingley.
Those intending to enter the
ministry and mission work are: E.
P. Hayes, missionary to China; R.
E. F. Aler and M. H. McCormick,
the ministry.
Those planning to enter business:
J. C. Knipp, C. W. McDowell and
C. H. Tinges.
Those undecided or unlisted: N.
M. Beck, H. C. Coffin, H. L. Dryden, R. Rosen and E. 0. Shaw.
Comparing the different professions, out of 29 men listed in the
class, medicine conies first with 9,
graduate work, second, with 6; law,
the ministry and business, third,
with 3 each, while those undecided
are 5.

The National City Bank of New
York has set a plan before the
faculty of Minnesota whereby it
will take students from fourteen
universities into its employ at $50
per month, and train them for
foreign service. The students are
to be chosen in their sophomore
year, must study the language ofthe country to which they wish to
be sent, and must work in the bank
•
two summers.
"Class scraps" were unanimously abolished at Penn State by a
mass-meeting of the student body.
At the same time, however, provisions were made whereby some
milder form of under-classmen activities may be introduced in their
stead.
One of the strangest methods of
earning money by college students
last year was that of blood transfusion. Twelve Harvard students
underwent this operation for which
each received $10.
In a recent report the dean of
Smith College refutes what she
says is the popular idea that the
college girl devotes a large part of
her time and money to amusing
herself.
Figures compiled from expense
accounts kept by all the 333 stu--.
dents for two months and by about
one-fourth of the total for the school
year show the average girl at
Smith spends 87.4 per cent, of her
money for necessities; 8.2 per cent.
for pleasure, including dues, recreation, contributions to church and
charity, and 4.2 per cent for books
and stationery.
The cutting evil at Yale University has been eliminated by means
of the "half-cut" system. If a student is unprepared, he may go to
class, signify that he does not wish
to recite, and be credited with onehalf cut. In this way he gets the
benefit of the lecture and the recitation. The system has proved very
satisfactory, both from the instructors' and the students' point of
view.
* *
Following the example set by
Minnesota, the honor system will be
introduced into football at the University of Pennsylvania next fall.
Each man will be placed on his
honor to keep in training and obey
regulations.

*

Gettysburg recently adopted an
honor system which provides for
the abolition of class scraps, tabooing of posters and elimination of
Ii azing.
Dartmouth College has a dramatic association with a membership of 200 men. The association
presents a play every three weeks
with an entire change of cast.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 17, 1916.

CORPS DRILLING AT HOMEWOOD

CLUB MAKES RECORD SCORE

Developing Rapidly in Execution of
Movements--Is Now Organized in
Company Form—Leaders Take
Turns at Command.

Scores 989 Out of Possible 1000 Against
Rensslaer—Indoor Season Over.
Hopkins Near Top of
the League.

Although the volunteer battalion
of the Johns Hopkins University
has had only two weeks of training
in the rudiments of military drill,
the men have taken hold of the
movements so well that on last
Wednesday at the drill ground in
front of the Academic Building at
Homewood it was possible for the
corps to organize in the regular
company formation and take up
"squads right" and "squads left,"
the two fundamental movements in
the school of the company.
H. Winslow was appointed by
Mr. Kistler to take charge of the
company on that day, and the training progressed rapidly under his
supervision. After forming the
company and appointing the experienced men corporals, file-closers
and guides, he explained the movements to be taken up and then put
the squads in charge of their assigned leaders. These men, after
reviewing the movements previously practiced, instructed the squads
how to execute "squads right" and
"squads left." After a period devoted to the performance of these
orders, the squads were again assembled in company formation, and
the whole company was put
through various new commands.
On Friday practically the same
routine was followed with the company under the command of B.
Baxley, '17. Mr. Kistler had intended on that day to have the company elect temporary officers to act
until examinations could be taken
for official positions as commissioned officers, but after consultation
with the squad leaders decided to
reject the plan as premature. In
its stead a better system is to be
followed out. Each leader, in succession from graduate student
down to freshman, is to have charge
of the company for one day, to
show his ability at commanding and
instructing in military drill. After
the list has been gone through, the
leaders will have had practical experience in preparation for the examination and the authorities will
have had an opportunity to judge
more wisely of the fitness of the
,. men.
Another scheme which is now
being carried out, is a school for
officers, which occurs on Tuesday
at 5 o'clock at Homewood. All
the .commands which are to be
taken up at the next general drill,
and every detail which will make
the corps more efficient, are discussed at length. Mr. Kistler is
anxious that all leaders he present
at these meetings as it is mainly
upon them that the responsibility
for the success of the movement
rests.
It is also imperative that all those
who have signed up for military
training appear at the drills, which
occur on Monday, Wednesday and

The Johns Hopkins University
Rifle Team finished its indoor season on last Saturday with the
record of losing only two' matches
out of thirteen. Moreover, in its
match with Rensslaer, which took
place last week, our squad made the
highest aggregate score shot by any
of the thireen teams in the National
Rifle Association-989 out of a possible 1,000. With such a score, although the winner has not yet been
officially determined, it is absolutely
certain that Hopkins won an overwhelming victory over its opponent.
The scores made in this match
were 197 made by J. Sanner, '18,
196 by P. Wiggins, 199 by H. A.
Rowland, 199 by W. Pratt and 198
by J. W. Young. Another victory
for the Hopkins team was that over
Harvard on April 1, which tallied
984 for Hopkins and 978 for its
opponents. These two triumphs
are especially pleasing as both
teams defeated had always been at
or near the top of the league. In
the match with Harvard, J. E. Sanner led with 199, W. B. Pratt shot
198, H. A. Rowland made 197, J.
M. C. Van Hulsteyn shot 198 and
P. R. Wiggins tallied 195.
It is practically certain that our
team stands at least among the first
five in the league. Out of a possible 13,000 points on the thirteen
matches, Hopkins has scored 12,585,
the average score being 968. The
individual averages of the men on
the team are also very high. They
are as follows: Pratt, 196.5; Van
Hulsteyn, 192.1; Rowland, 191.4;
Chisholm, 190.3; Wiggins, 190.1;
Sanner, 189.5; Young, 188.3;
Smith, i86.8; Randall, 184.0, and
Konze, 179.1.
The success of the indoor season
justifies the hope that the Hopkins
squad will win first honors in the
coming spring season which lasts
from May 15 •to 21, at Saunders
Range, near Annapolis. The Krag
rifles, which the members of the
team received direct from the United States Government, have arrived, and the men are already
beginning to test them on outdoor
ranges. Practices are usually held
on Saturday at Saunders Range,
Annapolis, and the men's expenses
are paid both ways by the Government.

TO SEND PARTY TO EAGLES MERE
Y. M. C. A. Expects to Be Represented
by Large Delegation at Annual Students' Conference--Total Expense for Trip, $33.

\\ ith but half a dozen weeks of
the academic year remaining, the
Young Men's •Christian Association of this University is making
definite plans for its delegation at
the Middle Atlantic Students' Conference, which will be held, as
usual, at Eagles Mere Park, Pa.,
immediately after the University
closes.
The conference will open on June
16 and will continue for ten days.
The total expenses of the trip for
a delegate will be $33, which will
include railroad fare and board at
the hotels.
The conference this year is expected to be unusually successful.
Among the speakers and leaders
present will be John R. Moot,
Robert E. Speer, Raymond Robbins, Harry Emerson Fosdick and
Sherwood 'Eddy, all of whom have
a national and even world-wide
reputation.
The talks and meetings will not
confine themselves to the study of
mission work, but will take up
problems.which confront every man
in all spheres of activity.
The week is not spent, however,
entirely in lectures and conferences.
In fact, the greater part of the day
is spent on the lake, in the woods,
or in inter-collegiate rivalry. Many
colleges from this section of the
country are represented at the conference, among the number being
Princeton, University of Pennsylvania, Penn State, Lehigh and Cornell.
Hopkins has always sent about
a score of men to 'Eagles Mere,
and expects to send an even larger
delegation this summer. Those
who are interested should see
Franklin Sutton, chairman of the
Eagles Mere committee; Pearce
Hayes, or Mr. Lindley, all of whom
have descriptive folders for distribution.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 17, 1916.

10
TENNIS MEN DOWN GETTYSBURG

SUNDAY TALKS TO HOPKINS MEN

Team Wins First Contest of Season by
Score of Four Matches to Two.
Makes Strong Showing
in Doubles.

Given Enthusiastic. Reception—Praises
University in Talk—"Don't Be a Boil
on the Neck of the Body Politic," He Exhorts.

On Saturday afternoon, in their
first match of the season, playing
on their opponents ground, the
Hopkins tennis team defeated Gettysburg, four matches to two.
All the games played were fast
and exciting, and the form displayed by all the players would not
have disgraced a mid-season showing. The courts were in good condition, and a large crowd witnessed
the games.
In the singles, Hopkins split
even, winning two matches and
losing two, but it succeeded in winning both of the finals. At one
time only did things look dark for
the Black and Blue, when, in the
first game of the doubles, Seecrest
and Swartz of Gettysburg defeated
Hammond and Allen of Hopkins by
the score of 6 to 4. In a superb
rally, however, by means of excellent team-work, the two latter men
came back in the second game,
winning 6 to 4. From that time on,
the result was on longer in doubt,
Hopkins winning every other game.
On April 19 the tennis team will
play Navy at Annapolis, and on
April 21 will meet Princeton at
Homewood. With the excellent
start afforded by the defeat over
such a strong team as Gettysburg,
the Hopkins men are confident of a
highly successful season;
The score of last Saturday's
match:

On Friday afternoon, after many
weeks of expectation, the students
of Johns Hopkins University had
the privilege of being addressed by
Billy Sunday in their own hall.
At the hour of twelve, McCoy
Hall was filled to overflowing, and
the audience was already manifesting its excitement by frequent outbursts of applause and song. When
at last Mr. Sunday appeared on the
platform, accompanied by Rodeheaver, he was given a hullabaloo
whose volume left no doubt as to
the enthusiasm behind it.
Mr. Eugene Levering introduced
Mr. Sunday with a few brief remarks. Rodeheaver then advanced
with his invincible trombone and
began proceedings by reading a
notice of Saturday's lacrosse game.
It was to be regretted that Hopkins had not warmed up earlier in
the campaign, he said, so that such
notices might have been read regularly in the tabernacle. The colleges and Mr. Sunday had always
worked together, he went on, with
mutual success. He then announced
"a drama in three parts," and played
"Yankee Doodle,""Dixie" and "The
Star - Spangled Banner. McCoy
Hall has seldom heard wilder bursts
of applause than those which followed that "drama."
Mr. Sunday now advanced to the
front of the platform. "I never
dared to dream that I would ever
have the honor of addressing Johns
Hopkins University, a university
whose fame extends throughout the
land, in person," he began, "and I
want to thank you now for the
privilege you are according me."
Then he launched into his sermon.
"The real purpose of education
is not only to inculcate a few facts,"
he said, "it is to discipline hearts.
Not all the• time can be spent in
polishing your brains.
"When you die, you want to
leave something more behind you
than the epitaph on a tombstone.
The world will take you at your
own worth. 'You can fool all of
the people some of the time and you
can fool some of the people all of
the time, but you can't fool all of
the people all of the time.'
"Do a common thing in an uncommon way. When I was a boy,
I was a janitor in a building, and
it was then that I realized what
that meant for the first time. A
jack-of-all-trades can't support
himself, let alone any girl who is
fool enough to marry him.
"Do one thing well. Don't be a
carbuncle on the neck of the body
politic; Know more about your
business than any one else does.
"Be careful of your time. Idleness is one of the biggest curses
known to mankind. Be careful and
painstaking. 'Trifles make perfec-

Archie's Neck.

Little Willie—in small boy stories
the central figure is nearly always
named Little Willie—came running
into the house, stuttering in his excitement.
"Mommer," he panted, "do you
know Archie Sloan's neck?"
"Do I know what?" asked his
mother.
"Do you know Archie Sloan's
neck ?" repeated her offspring.
"I know Archie Sloan," answered
the puzzled parent; "so I suppose
I must know his neck. Why?"
"Well," said Willie,"he just now
fell into the back-water up to it."
